summary: The document is a classified CIA message detailing the difficulties in securing a Mexican visa for a Cuban individual, referred to as A-1, through the Mexican Consulate in Miami or San Juan. It outlines bureaucratic obstacles and the Mexican government's hesitance, fearing Cubans might become public charges. The message proposes utilizing high-level Mexican contacts or Cuban intermediaries with such connections to speed up the visa process, highlighting the strategic use of personal interests by officials to overcome bureaucratic barriers. It also cautions against concurrent actions by A-1 and another party to prevent complications.
key_findings: Obtaining a Mexican visa for Cubans involved significant bureaucratic delays and reluctance from the Mexican government.
Leveraging high-level Mexican contacts or Cuban intermediaries was considered the most effective method to expedite the visa process.
The strategy included using personal connections and interests to navigate through bureaucratic challenges.
The CIA supported the use of personal channels by officials to maintain operational discretion.
The document warned against simultaneous actions by different parties to avoid suspicion or further complicating the visa process.
